title: 112_hr1509
content: The Act titled "Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2012" prohibits the inclusion of Social Security account numbers on Medicare cards. The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2012 prohibits displaying Social Security numbers on Medicare cards, requiring cost-effective procedures to ensure compliance. The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2012 mandates the removal of Social Security numbers from Medicare cards, with a cost-effective process established by the Secretary of Health and Human Services to minimize disruption to beneficiaries and healthcare providers. This process may involve using a unique Medicare beneficiary identifier that is not a Social Security number externally, which can be converted to a Social Security number internally. The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2012 requires the removal of Social Security numbers from Medicare cards. A unique Medicare beneficiary identifier will be used externally, which can be converted to a Social Security number internally. The effective date for the new cards will be within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will oversee the reissuance of Medicare cards that comply with the new requirements. The Medicare Identity Theft Prevention Act of 2012 mandates the removal of Social Security numbers from Medicare cards. A new unique Medicare beneficiary identifier will replace it. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can allow individuals to apply for reissued Medicare cards earlier in exceptional circumstances. Funding for the reissuance will come from the Medicare Improvement Fund. The Commissioner of Social Security and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will enter into an agreement to provide funding for the Commissioner's responsibilities under this section. The agreement will include scheduled intervals for funding and require an annual accounting. The agreement between the Commissioner of Social Security and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will include annual accounting of costs and funds provided for implementation. The Comptroller General will conduct semi-annual financial audits of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Social Security Administration's expenditures in implementing a specific clause. Reports on expenditures will be submitted to relevant committees on a semi-annual basis from 2013 to 2021. The Medicare Smart Card Technology Study and Report will be conducted as per Section 3. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on whether Medicare should use smart card technology for beneficiary and provider cards. The study will examine provider investment levels, implementation costs, private insurance adoption, and the potential for reducing identity theft. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the use of smart card technology for Medicare beneficiary and provider cards to improve care quality, billing accuracy, reduce fraud, and enhance beneficiary access to services. A report will be submitted to relevant committees within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on smart card technology for Medicare cards to improve care quality, billing accuracy, reduce fraud, and enhance beneficiary access. The report may include recommendations on smart card technology use in the Medicare program. The House of Representatives passed the bill on December 20, 2012. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
